Authors:
Alessandro Pirondi, Miloslav Kitner, Mirco Iotti, Ales
Lebeda, Marina Collina
Title:
Genetic structure and phylogeny of Italian and Czech
populations of the cucurbit powdery mildew fungus Golovinomyces orontii
inferred by Multilocus Sequence Typing
Keywords:
Bayesian inference, haplotype, inoculum dispersion, sexual
recombination, species complex
Abstract:
Cucurbit powdery mildew caused by Golovinomyces orontii is
a serious disease that affect cucurbit crops in temperate areas. In
North of Italy, the species is responsible of the first infections at
the beginning of the growing season. However, chasmothecia have never
been recorded in the area and the impact of either asexual or sexual
reproduction of the species still remains to be determined. To
investigate and compare the genetic structure of Italian populations
with respect to those from Czech Republic, where chasmothecia are
sporadically recorded, seven housekeeping gene fragments (ef1-Î±, csI,
ITS, H3, tub2, IGS and mtLSU) were amplified and used in a multilocus
sequence typing (MLST) scheme. The four-gamete test was performed to
detect recombination between and within populations. Phylogeny was also
inferred using Bayesian inference. Results from MLST revealed the
presence of 140 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) and the existence
of 13 different sequence types (STs). Haplotype diversity was higher in
Czech Republic than Italian population, which presented a higher
frequency of ST3 (seventeen isolates) and ST7 (eight isolates).
Phylogenetic analysis revealed the existence of two main distinct
phylogenetic groups that were also highly genetically different,
confirming that G. orontii is a species complex. Recombination was
detected both within and between the two geographical populations but
only within one phylogenetic group, supporting the genetic isolation of
the two groups. Our data suggest that groups 1 and 3 belonging to the IX
lineage of the genus Golovinomyces prevail in Czech Republic and Italy,
the populations in this latter country could be predominantly clonal,
while sexual reproduction may occasionally occur due to the introduction
of genotypes similar to isolates from Czech Republic.
